ell_alignment.notes: Pre-teach evaluative vocabulary (tricky, challenging, successful, strategy, goal). Provide bilingual reflection prompts. Model using think-alouds. Allow reflection in home language with translation support. Use visuals (emoji scales, star ratings) alongside language.
scaffolds: Sentence frames in English and home language
Visual reflection tools (emoji faces, slider scales)
Partner reflection: talk with peer before whole-class sharing
Word banks for feelings and strategies

assessment_timing.initial_check: Start of Term 1 (baseline: can student name one thing they did?)
assessment_timing.formative_checkpoints: Built into every unit reflection, learning conference, and self-assessment opportunity
assessment_timing.summative_evidence: Portfolio of reflections showing growth in specificity and independence across the year

teaching_strategies: Model reflective language daily through think-alouds: 'I'm going to try this strategy first because…'
Co-create 'I can' statements and success criteria with students
Use 'Two Stars and a Wish' feedback protocol (two strengths, one goal)
Provide structured reflection time after every learning experience (even 2 minutes)
Teach growth mindset explicitly: brain science, power of 'yet', mistakes as learning
Create anchor charts showing reflective sentence frames by purpose (evaluating, planning, describing process)
Integrate reflection across all subjects, not just literacy

next_steps.if_emerging: Use reflection prompts with only two choices ('Did you use a pencil or a pen?'). Focus on naming actions, not evaluating. Model constantly.
next_steps.if_developing: Introduce 'because' to add reasoning ('I did well at spelling because I used the sound wall'). Practice identifying one strength and one challenge.
next_steps.if_consolidating: Increase specificity ('I need to work on' → 'I need to work on remembering to reread my writing to check for periods'). Link strategies to outcomes.
next_steps.if_proficient_or_exceeding: Encourage self-directed goal-setting. Teach strategy transfer ('This strategy worked in math, so I could try it in science'). Develop learning portfolios.

cross_curricular_connections: Mathematics: Reflecting on problem-solving strategies and accuracy
Science: Evaluating investigations and planning next steps in inquiry
Physical Education: Describing skill improvement and practice plans
Arts: Reflecting on creative choices and artistic growth
Social Sciences: Considering learning about self and community
common_misconceptions: Misconception: 'Reflection is only for end-of-unit' → Teach: Reflection happens continuously—after each task, daily, weekly
Misconception: 'Young children can't reflect meaningfully' → Teach: With scaffolds and modeling, even 5-year-olds can articulate strengths and challenges
Misconception: 'Reflection is just describing what you did' → Teach: Deep reflection includes evaluation, strategy identification, and forward planning

success_examples.context: Year 2 mathematics reflection after addition unit
success_examples.student_reflection: I learned to use a number line to add. First I find the bigger number. Then I jump forward. I did well at counting my jumps carefully. I found tricky when the numbers were big like 47 + 28. My goal is to get faster at adding in my head for small numbers. I will practice doubles because they help.
success_examples.teacher_note: Clear process description, specific strategy naming, honest self-assessment, actionable goal with reasoning.

success_examples.student_voice: I'm proud of my story because I used interesting words like 'gigantic' instead of 'big'. I got that from our read-aloud. Next time I want to add more dialogue because it makes stories more exciting. I need to work on remembering my speech marks.
success_examples.teacher_note: Identifies strength with evidence (word choice from mentor text). Clear next step with reasoning. Specific editing goal.

llm_metadata.notes_for_rag_systems: Essential for: formative assessment practices, student agency development, cross-curricular application, growth mindset teaching, self-regulated learning, Key Competencies integration
llm_metadata.caveat: While rooted in oral language outcomes, this OMI emphasizes cross-curricular metacognition and may be better categorized under Key Competencies or 'Learning Languages' (thinking about language and learning) rather than solely English. Verify alignment with curriculum documents on reflective practice and learner agency.
